body: Trivial change self-approving

Moving AzkabanTags.java form gobblin-azkaban to gobblin-util. Causes a circular dependency if gobblin-data-management imports gobblin-azkaban. 
Merging as this is just a move.

@zliu41 LogCopier works correctly if maximum file size is specified. The Web UI is still a pain as it represents it as one large file, making opening, downloading, etc. really slow. I can imagine that this will only get worse as the Yarn application runs even longer.
LGTM

@zliu41 I don't like this change. Using non-singular fields makes it very hard to create `SimpleHiveSpecs` with activities or predicates. Removing the `@Builder` makes adding new fields in the future error prone and tedious. Why not just make the fields protected?

How to make them protected? `@Singular` will automatically declare them as private, and adding `@Getter` is not allowed.

One way is to add the getter methods in builder manually.
Turned out I only needed to access `path`, `table` and `partition` in the builder, so added `@Getter` annotation to these fields.
LGTM
LGTM
Minor comments, in general looks good. Thanks for making these changes.

I think you need to rebase your commit, otherwise this generally LGTM.

I'm referring to the Hadoop Resource Manager web UI.

LGTM
I'm going to attempt to review this as Chavdar may be busy with other things.
@sahilTakiar Updated

It's ok to remove the timeout on getting a record from the queue which is no longer needed, but I think there should still be a timeout on putting a record into the queue. The benefit of having a timeout for put is that, if there are multiple forks in a task, and one fork is slow (hence its queue is often full), the task can timeout the put for this fork and go to the next fork.

Otherwise the entire task is blocked by the slow fork.
LGTM

@zliu41 the entire task will be blocked by a slow fork at the moment anyhow. Wich is wanted behaviour i guess. IMO the gain of the whole looping thing in Task,processRecord() is very little, it just shifts the place where they see nor record for long time from the position between n to n+1 to n-1 to n. This only has an impact when its the last record. In this case the fast forks will still be done faster then the problematic fork that caused the blocking. I am actually in favour of throwing this `while (!allPutsSucceeded) {` away, as layed out the benefit is not really there IMO.
@Kaiserchen that's true. Then can you change the return type of `putRecord` to void.
@kadaan is this PR ready for review? Can you also add some documentation about this under `gobblin-docs/user-guide/Gobblin-on-Yarn.md`

Yes, it is ready for review.  Please consider the following while reviewing:

> The only part I'm a little unsure about is the cancellation of a running job if the connection to ZK is lost. I think it is needed to ensure that duplicate jobs are not running, but I'm not sure if the mean of cancellation is correct.

Is it possible to keep multiple version of the `put` method? That would be ideal as we won't break any existing users of the `JobHistoryStore`. We can make the old `put` method as `deprecated`, and when Gobblin goes through a major version change we can delete it.

What are "path tokens" exactly? Why is it necessary to do this to the dataset urn when writing to the `FsStateStore`, it seems like a pretty major restriction to force all dataset urn's to be of a certain length.

It may be better to have a separate class that extends `FsStateStore`, so we can add the method to the new class.
I just need to find some time to go through the code, will try to take a look today.
Two small comments, LGTM otherwise.

File token is a single name in a Path (e.g. /data/my/path, the tokens are "data", "my", and "path"). This has to be done because character : is invalid in HDFS, / has special semantics, and HDFS does not allow any token to be longer than 250 bytes.

Is that a bug in HDFS, are there any upstream JIRAs we can link this PR to? Would it be better to throw an exception rather than shorten the token? This way users are confused when they see a table name randomly shortened.

Also, when I tried to test this, the following `-mkdir` command worked, is there some exception that is suppose to be thrown?

```
hdfs dfs -mkdir 
```
or @ydai1124 can you review?
LGTM

It is not a bug, see:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HDFS-6055

Apparently it was introduced in 2.4 for compatibility with local file systems.
